bibl.title: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, August 6, 1950

div1.p: Rodriguez Leon would like her father's papers returned to her because she has promised them for a permanent exhibit. She believes that the data shows her father, Agramonte, was in Havana at the time of Lazear's death.

div1.head: Letter from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, August 6, 1950
div1.opener:
K Street No. 254,
Vedado, Havana, Cuba.
August 6, 1950.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
102-110 Second Ave. S.W.
Rochester, Minnesota.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I was sorry to hear through Mr. Moran that you had been
ill. That explains why I received no answer to my brief
note of congratulation, at the time of the write-up in
Time, concerning your valuable research on rheumatism.
I trust you are well now, and that you will allow your_
self some rest in the future. Active and enthusiastic
workers like you are apt to burn their candles at both
ends, and that certainly brings no good results.

I am writing you under considerable pressure, the Summer
Session of the University being in full swing, and I am
also working with the Educational Department on the reor_
ganization of the teaching of English from the bottom up.
We Cubans either work at a cyclone rate or nothing is ac_
complished.

In the course of this work I have had the opportunity
to contact some influential people in the present gov_
ernment, and there is a move to do something towards
a monument of the work of the Yellow Fever investiga_
tors. This will include Finlay of course, but due credit
will be given the U.S. Army Board. I'm rather skepti_
cal about the ultimate achievement of the committee -
a library for research in tropical medicine -, but
I feel it is my duty to cooperate in all I can. They
are planning with the American Embassy to have a perm_
anenet display of all available documents, during the
several weeks of a lecture course by famous foreign
and native doctors, beginning next September. I have
promised to provide my father's papers, and now it is
up to you to make it possible for me to keep my promise.

Since May 1948, when I decided against haveing Dr Nogueira
bring them back, and when my letter suggesting a contact
with a friend of mine in New York who was coming to visit
me, missed you during you trip to that very city in May 1949 missed you,
I have been trying to find someone who might happen to
pass near your part of the country. I also hoped you
might come our way again. Two years have gone by, wishing
to avoid the expense of sending all those things by reg_
istered mail airmail, yet anxiously hoping to get my fa_
Dr. Philip S. Hench (2)
ther documents back. I am seriously worried that they
might be lost in transit. We have the photostats of
course, but my proofs must be the originals, to be con_
vincing when the time comes to make important announce_
ments. I see no other way of for you to return them to
me, and I am now anxious to have them at hand during the
debate that is sure to arise from the course.

Will you see that they are sent to me right away? I see
no chance of going up for them myself, or of your bring_
ing them to me, and I want to have all my fathers papers
classified, mounted and in use by Sept 11th. I am enclos_
ing a list of the documents you borrowed from me, in case
your secretary wishes to use it for reference.

I think I should pay all, or a part at least, of the mail_
ing expenses. Please let me know what they are. I am
sorry to rush you after so many months, but my urgency
responds to the possibility of getting something done
at last, by the Cuban government.

Knowing you are sincerely interested in the subject, I
shall keep you posted on all future developments.

Please notify me as to the date of mailing, that I may
start worrying in earnest. Take care of yourself. Our
best regards to your charming wife,

closer.seg:
P.S. By the way, were you ever able to complete the record
with regard to my fathers absence from Havana in 1900?
Some additional data seems to re-establish the fact of
his presence in Havana at the time of Lazear's death,
in spite of that trip to U.S. I wish I could see Major
Reed's personal correspondence of the time. There seems
to have been a letter from my father, and what is more
valuable, a note from convalescent Carroll - afterwards
antagonistic to Agramonte - describing the details of La_
zear's death. Do you think Gen. W. Reed would have those
papers, now that his mother died?
you rep
Please let me hear from you as soon as possible., about
returning the documents. Thank you!
